issues.title: Missing Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) Safe Harbor Provisions
issues.description: California school districts must comply with federal DMCA requirements, including designation of a copyright agent and implementation of notice-and-takedown procedures for online content. This is particularly critical given the district's use of digital platforms and online educational materials. The policy/regulation set lacks any reference to DMCA compliance procedures.

legal_citations.text: Service providers must designate an agent to receive notifications of claimed infringement and implement notice-and-takedown procedures to maintain safe harbor protections.

issues.required_language: The district shall designate a copyright agent to receive notices of claimed copyright infringement and shall implement procedures for responding to such notices in accordance with the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. The district shall maintain current registration of its designated agent with the U.S. Copyright Office.

issues.title: Missing Technology, Education and Copyright Harmonization (TEACH) Act Provisions
issues.description: The TEACH Act provides specific exemptions for educational institutions' use of copyrighted materials in distance learning and online education. Given the prevalence of online and hybrid learning, districts must have policies addressing TEACH Act compliance requirements, including technological safeguards and access restrictions.

legal_citations.text: Educational institutions may use copyrighted works in distance education under specific conditions including technological safeguards, access restrictions, and institutional copyright policies.

issues.required_language: For distance learning and online educational activities, the district shall comply with TEACH Act requirements including: implementing technological measures to prevent retention and redistribution of transmitted materials, limiting access to enrolled students, providing copyright information to faculty and students, and ensuring materials are directly related to teaching content.

issues.title: Missing Creative Commons and Open Educational Resources Guidelines
issues.description: Modern educational environments extensively use Creative Commons licensed materials and Open Educational Resources (OER). The policy lacks guidance on proper attribution, license compliance, and use restrictions for these materials, which have become standard in K-12 education.

legal_citations.text: California encourages the use of open educational resources and requires proper compliance with licensing terms.

issues.required_language: Staff shall comply with Creative Commons and other open licensing terms when using Open Educational Resources, including proper attribution, adherence to license restrictions (commercial use, derivative works, share-alike requirements), and verification of license compatibility when combining materials.

issues.title: Outdated Off-Air Recording Guidelines
issues.description: The regulation contains detailed off-air recording guidelines that may not reflect current streaming and digital content realities. While not legally deficient, these provisions should be updated to address modern digital content delivery methods and streaming services used in education.

legal_citations.text: Fair use analysis must consider current technological methods of content delivery and educational use.

issues.required_language: Guidelines for recording and using digital streaming content, educational platform materials, and subscription-based educational services shall comply with service agreements and fair use principles, with consideration for technological protection measures and licensing terms.

issues.title: Missing Student Copyright Education Requirements
issues.description: While the policy mentions that computer-related instruction should address software piracy, it lacks comprehensive requirements for student education about copyright, fair use, and digital citizenship across all grade levels and subject areas.

legal_citations.text: Districts should provide instruction on digital citizenship including respect for intellectual property rights.

issues.required_language: The district shall provide age-appropriate instruction to students on copyright law, fair use principles, proper attribution, and digital citizenship as part of the regular curriculum across grade levels.
